Biography

Norma Shearer lived in Quebec, Canada.

Norma Shearer is Notable.

Norma Shearer won the 1929/30 Academy Award for Best Actress

Norma Shearer was a Californian.

Edith Norma Shearer was a Canadian-American actress and Hollywood star from 1925 through 1942. Shearer often played spunky, sexually liberated ingenues on the silver screen. She was the first person to be nominated five times for an Academy Award for acting, winning Best Actress for her performance in the 1930 film The Divorcee.

She was born as Edith Norma Shearer 11 August 1902 in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, the daughter of Andrew Shearer and Edith Fisher.[1] She immigrated from Canada to New York, U.S. with her mother and siblings. She later moved to California following her dream to be in the movies. She applied for US citizenship in Feb 1931.[2]

She was married twice. Her first husband was Irving Thalberg, a film producer, whom she married 29 September 1927 in Beverley Hills, California.[3] They were the parents of Irving Jr. (1930-1987)[4] and Katherine (1935-2006). Her husband Irving died in 1936.

Her second husband was Martin Jacques Arrouge, whom she married 23 Aug 1942 in Los Angeles, California.[5]

Norma died 12 June 1983 in Woodland Hills, California.[6] Her remains were buried at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale, California.[7]

Obituary:[8]

Norma Shearer, Movies' Elegant Heroine of '30s

Los Angeles--Norma Shearer, one of the famed Hollywood stars of the 1920s and 1930s, died Sunday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital near here, a hospital spokesman said yesterday.

Her birth year has been variously given as 1900 and 1904. She was born as Edith Norma Shearer in Westmount, a Montreal suburb, and went to public schools in Montreal. Her penniless family sold its dog and its piano to pay the way to her first fling at show business in New York.

From there it was not long before her beauty, her hard work, her charm and her marriage to film executive Irving Thalberg had made her a leading light of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studios and a pillar of California film society.

In her early Hollywood days, she played innocent, girlish heroines on the silent screen. Her best known were "He Who Gets Slapped," which starred Lon Chaney in 1924, and "The Student Prince," in which Ramon Novarro had the title role in 1927.

She made the transition to sound movies with ease and success, and her voice was heard largely in sophisticated, somewhat daring parts. Again and again she played elegant heroines with a tinge of wickedness, as in "The Last of Mrs. Cheyney," which appeared in 1929.

Her starring role in a 1930 film, "The Divorcee," won her an Academy Award, and she was nominated for four others.

She is remembered largely for her repeated portrayals of rich and worldly ladies in films that, though not very challenging,, were enlivened by a moderate raciness--or what seemed like raciness in those days. It was reflected in such titles as "The Divorcee," "Strangers May Kiss," "A Free Soul," and "Riptide."

She also made some forays into high comedy, such as Noel Coward's "Private Lives," in 1931. ANd she plunged into costumed period films, such as the sentimental "Smilin' Through," "The Barretts of Wimpole Street," which was an enormous critical and commercial hit, and the lavish "Marie Antoinette," her first film after Thalberg's death in 1937.

In 1942, she married Martin Arrouge, 28, a ski instructor. She is survived by two children of her marriage with Thalberg, Irving Thalberg Jr. and Katherine."
